questions.question: Which services are in the AWS storage category? (Select TWO.)

explanation.summary: Amazon S3 (Simple Storage Service) is AWS's object storage service, designed to store and retrieve any amount of data from anywhere on the web. It's one of the foundational storage services in AWS.
keyPoints: Object storage for any type of data (images, videos, backups, logs, etc.)
Virtually unlimited storage capacity
Multiple storage classes for different access patterns and costs
Built-in versioning, lifecycle management, and replication
Integrates with most AWS services
examples: Hosting static website content (HTML, CSS, images)
Storing application backups and disaster recovery data
Data lakes for big data analytics
Content distribution for media files
Archiving compliance data with S3 Glacier

explanation.summary: AWS Lambda is a compute service, not a storage service. Lambda is a serverless compute platform that runs code in response to events without requiring you to manage servers.
explanation.why: Lambda executes code (functions) - it doesn't store data long-term. While Lambda functions can read from and write to storage services like S3, Lambda itself is categorized under Compute services.

explanation.summary: Amazon EFS is a fully managed, elastic file storage service designed to provide scalable file storage for use with AWS compute services and on-premises servers. It's part of AWS's storage category, offering shared file system access.
keyPoints: Fully managed file storage that grows and shrinks automatically
Can be mounted by multiple EC2 instances simultaneously
Uses standard file system interface (NFS v4)
Serverless - no infrastructure to manage
Automatic scaling to petabytes without disrupting applications
Pay only for storage used
examples: Shared file storage for multiple EC2 instances running a web application
Content management systems requiring shared file access
Development environments where teams need shared code repositories
Container storage for Docker containers
Big data analytics requiring high-throughput file access

explanation.summary: Amazon EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) is a compute service that provides virtual servers in the cloud, not a storage service.
explanation.why: EC2 provides the computing power to run applications - it's virtual machines where your code executes. While EC2 instances can attach storage volumes (like EBS), EC2 itself is categorized under Compute services, not Storage.

explanation.summary: Amazon ECS is a container orchestration service, not a storage service. It's categorized under Compute/Containers services.
explanation.why: ECS manages and orchestrates Docker containers, running containerized applications across a cluster of EC2 instances or on AWS Fargate. It handles container deployment, scaling, and management - all compute functions, not storage.

questions.question: An administrator wants to create new users for their AWS account and assign permissions to these users. Which service should the administrator use?

explanation.summary: Amazon Route 53 is a DNS (Domain Name System) web service, not an identity and access management service.
explanation.why: Route 53 translates domain names (like www.example.com) into IP addresses that computers use to connect to each other. It handles domain registration, DNS routing, and health checking - not user management or permissions.

explanation.summary: AWS Organizations is a service for managing multiple AWS accounts, not for managing individual user identities and permissions within a single account.
explanation.why: Organizations helps you centrally manage and govern multiple AWS accounts. It's used for billing consolidation, account creation, and applying policies across accounts - not for creating and managing individual users. For user management, you need IAM.

explanation.summary: AWS IAM is the service specifically designed for creating and managing users, groups, and roles, and assigning granular permissions to control access to AWS resources. It's the central security service for identity and access management in AWS.
keyPoints: Create and manage IAM users with unique credentials
Organize users into groups for easier permission management
Create IAM roles for applications and services
Assign fine-grained permissions using policies
Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) for enhanced security
Provide temporary security credentials for federated users
howItWorks: Administrator creates an IAM user with username and password
Administrator attaches policies to the user (or adds user to a group with policies)
Policies define what AWS services and resources the user can access
User signs in with their credentials and can only perform allowed actions
Administrator can modify permissions anytime by updating policies
examples: Creating a 'Developers' group with EC2 and S3 access, then adding developer users to the group
Creating an individual user for a contractor with read-only access to specific S3 buckets
Setting up an IAM role for an EC2 instance to access DynamoDB without embedding credentials
Enabling MFA for admin users who can delete resources
Creating a policy that allows users to manage only their own resources
explanation.additionalInfo: IAM is free to use - you pay only for the AWS resources your users access. IAM policies follow the principle of least privilege: users start with no permissions and you explicitly grant only what they need.

explanation.summary: Amazon EC2 is a compute service for running virtual servers, not an identity and access management service.
explanation.why: EC2 provides virtual machines where you run applications. It has nothing to do with creating user accounts or managing permissions. For user and permission management, you need IAM.

questions.question: Which of the following are AWS service categories? (Select TWO.)

explanation.summary: Data warehouse is a type of service or use case, not an AWS service category. Amazon Redshift is a data warehouse service, but 'Data warehouse' itself is not a category.
explanation.why: AWS organizes services into categories like Compute, Storage, Database, Networking, Security, and Analytics. 'Data warehouse' describes what a service does (like Amazon Redshift), not a category of services.

explanation.summary: Compute is an official AWS service category that includes services providing processing power to run applications and workloads. This category contains virtual servers, containers, serverless functions, and other computing resources.
keyPoints: Amazon EC2 - Virtual servers in the cloud
AWS Lambda - Serverless compute (run code without servers)
Amazon ECS - Container orchestration service
Amazon EKS - Managed Kubernetes service
AWS Elastic Beanstalk - Platform for deploying web applications
AWS Fargate - Serverless compute for containers
examples: Using EC2 to host a web application on virtual machines
Running Lambda functions to process uploaded images
Deploying microservices in ECS containers
Running a Kubernetes cluster with EKS

explanation.summary: Security, Identity, and Compliance is an official AWS service category containing services that help you protect your data, manage access, meet compliance requirements, and maintain security across your AWS infrastructure.
keyPoints: AWS IAM - Identity and access management
Amazon Cognito - User authentication for apps
AWS KMS - Key management service for encryption
AWS Shield - DDoS protection
AWS WAF - Web application firewall
Amazon GuardDuty - Threat detection service
AWS Security Hub - Centralized security management
AWS Certificate Manager - SSL/TLS certificates
examples: Using IAM to control who can access your AWS resources
Encrypting S3 buckets with KMS keys
Protecting your website from DDoS attacks with Shield
Monitoring for malicious activity with GuardDuty
Managing SSL certificates for your website with Certificate Manager

explanation.summary: Availability Zones are infrastructure components, not a service category. They are physically isolated data centers within AWS Regions where you deploy your resources.
explanation.why: Availability Zones are part of AWS's global infrastructure architecture. They're locations where services run, not a category of services themselves.

explanation.summary: Amazon Route 53 is a specific AWS service (DNS service), not a service category. It belongs to the Networking & Content Delivery category.
explanation.why: Service categories group multiple related services together. Route 53 is one service within the Networking category, alongside services like VPC, CloudFront, and Elastic Load Balancing.

questions.question: Which compute service makes it possible for users to create virtual machines in the cloud?

explanation.summary: Amazon EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) is AWS's core service for creating and managing virtual machines in the cloud. EC2 provides resizable compute capacity, allowing you to launch virtual servers (called 'instances') with your choice of operating system, CPU, memory, storage, and networking.
keyPoints: Launch virtual machines (instances) in minutes
Choose from hundreds of instance types optimized for different workloads
Select your operating system (Linux, Windows, macOS)
Full control over the virtual machine configuration
Scale capacity up or down based on demand
Pay only for the compute time you use
howItWorks: Select an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) with your preferred OS
Choose an instance type (defines CPU, memory, storage, network capacity)
Connect to your virtual machine via SSH (Linux) or RDP (Windows)
examples: Launching a t2.micro instance to host a personal WordPress blog
Creating multiple m5.large instances for a web application backend
Running Windows Server instances for enterprise applications
Deploying GPU-powered instances for machine learning training
Setting up development and testing environments
explanation.additionalInfo: EC2 is AWS's Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) offering - you get virtual machines just like physical servers, but without buying or maintaining hardware. You have complete control including root/administrator access.

explanation.summary: AWS Batch is a service for running batch computing workloads, not for directly creating virtual machines. It does use EC2 instances behind the scenes, but Batch focuses on job scheduling and management.
explanation.why: AWS Batch automatically provisions compute resources and runs batch jobs. While it uses EC2 instances internally, you don't directly create or manage VMs with Batch - you submit jobs and Batch handles the infrastructure.

explanation.summary: AWS Elastic Beanstalk is a Platform as a Service (PaaS) that simplifies deploying and managing applications. It provisions and manages infrastructure for you, including EC2 instances, but you don't directly create VMs.
explanation.why: Beanstalk automatically handles deployment details like capacity provisioning, load balancing, and auto-scaling. You upload your application code, and Beanstalk manages the underlying EC2 instances. It's higher-level than directly creating VMs.

explanation.summary: AWS Lambda is a serverless compute service where you run code without managing servers or virtual machines. You don't create VMs with Lambda - AWS handles all infrastructure.
explanation.why: Lambda is Function as a Service (FaaS). You upload your code, and Lambda automatically runs it in response to events. There are no VMs to create, configure, or manage - that's the whole point of serverless.

questions.question: Which service can customers use to provision a logically isolated section of the AWS Cloud to establish a virtual network?

explanation.summary: Amazon Aurora is a relational database service, not a networking service. It's a MySQL and PostgreSQL-compatible database engine.
explanation.why: Aurora stores and manages data in databases. It has nothing to do with creating virtual networks or network isolation. For networking, you need VPC.

explanation.summary: Amazon VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) is the service that lets you provision a logically isolated section of the AWS Cloud where you can launch AWS resources in a virtual network that you define. You have complete control over your virtual networking environment.
keyPoints: Create isolated virtual networks within AWS
Define your own IP address range (CIDR blocks)
Create subnets to organize resources
Configure route tables to control traffic flow
Set up internet gateways for internet access
Use security groups and network ACLs for security
Connect to on-premises networks with VPN or Direct Connect
howItWorks: Define a VPC with an IP address range (e.g., 10.0.0.0/16)
Create public and private subnets within the VPC
Launch EC2 instances and other resources into subnets
Configure security groups to control inbound/outbound traffic
Set up internet gateways for public subnets
Use NAT gateways for private subnets to access internet
Optionally connect your VPC to your on-premises network
examples: Creating a VPC with public subnets for web servers and private subnets for databases
Isolating development, testing, and production environments in separate VPCs
Building a multi-tier application with web, application, and database layers in different subnets
Connecting your AWS VPC to your corporate data center via VPN
Setting up peering between VPCs to allow resources to communicate across VPCs
explanation.additionalInfo: Every AWS account comes with a default VPC in each region, but most organizations create custom VPCs for better security and control. VPC is free - you only pay for optional services like NAT gateways or VPN connections.

explanation.summary: Amazon Route 53 is a DNS (Domain Name System) service, not a service for creating virtual networks.
explanation.why: Route 53 routes end-user requests to your applications by translating domain names to IP addresses. It doesn't create isolated networks or manage network infrastructure - that's VPC's job.

explanation.summary: Amazon ECS is a container orchestration service, not a networking service. It manages Docker containers but doesn't create virtual networks.
explanation.why: ECS launches and manages containers on EC2 instances or Fargate. While ECS resources run within VPCs, ECS itself doesn't create or manage virtual networks - you use VPC for that.
